article.title: A Methodology for Test and Evaluation of Information Retrieval Systems
article.author: Goffman, W.Newill, V.A.
article.text: A recognition of the importance of useful evaluative techniques is an indirect or secondary result of the hugely expanded national investment in scientific research. Such recognition has followed the expenditure of much time and money on the development of information systems which utilize advances in information handling and data processing (primarily computer-oriented) to handle the "explosion" of recorded information. Information scientists from a typically diverse group of parent disciplines are now cooperating not only to develop methodologies of evaluation of such systems, but to apply them.
